questions.question: During a laparoscopic intra-abdominal surgery, the surgeon has to insufflate the peritoneal cavity. Which of the following statements is true regarding the Veress needle technique?

options.A: It is an open technique for creating pneumoperitoneum
options.B: The positioning of the needle is confirmed by a laparoscopic camera
options.C: Veress needle is a spring-loaded needle
options.D: It has a sharp inner stylet that deploys in the peritoneal cavity

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Veress needle is a spring-loaded needle Explanation: Veress needle is a spring-loaded needle used to create a pneumoperitoneum. Methods of creating pneumoperitoneum. Closed technique Open technique Veress needle and/or visual entry trocar (Option A) The Veress needle is a spring-loaded needle (Option C) . It has: An outer sharp bevel that cuts. A spring-loaded blunt inner stylet (Option D) deploys once it enters the peritoneum and protects from injuries to the bowel and vessels. Inserted at the umbilical region or other sites like Palmer’s point. Once position is confirmed (by the hanging drop method or abdominal pressure reading of <10mmHg), CO2 insufflation is started slowly until a pressure of 12-15mmHg is reached. The needle is then removed, and an optical primary port is placed. Veress needle: Hasson’s or modified Hasson’s Umbilicus is the preferred site for a 10-12mm initial port placement. A blunt-tipped 10 to 12-mm trocar is pushed through an incision made through the decussation inferior to the cicatrix of the umbilicus. The laparoscopic camera is used to confirm the successful placement. (Option B) Then CO2 gas insufflation is started at low flow (1-4 litres per minute) Increased to a maximum pressure of 15 mmHg with a maximum flow rate of 20L/min . Trocar:

questions.question: A patient who has undergone gastric banding is being advised on postoperative nutritional guidelines. Which of the following supplements is specifically recommended for this patient to prevent deficiency?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Vitamin D Explanation: Nutritional guidelines post-bariatric surgery: After gastric banding Multivitamin Mineral supplement Thiamine if vomiting Vitamin D (Option D) Iron. After sleeve gastrectomy, forms of gastric bypass, biliopancreatic diversion/duodenal switch (BPD/DS), single-anastomosis duodenoileal bypass with sleeve gastrectomy (SADI-S) As for gastric banding + Selenium (Option A) Copper Zinc (Option C) Folic acid (Option B) Vitamins B12, A, E, K. (BPD/DS, SADI-S may require higher doses) Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1190

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient undergoes bariatric surgery and is at risk for postoperative complications. What is the most common cause of 30-day mortality following bariatric surgery?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Pulmonary embolism Explanation: Perioperative Mortality of Bariatric Surgery: Overall mortality rates Perioperative mortality for bariatric surgery is low (<0.5%) and declining but can reach 2.0% or higher in some patient groups. Common causes of 30-day mortality after bariatric surgery Pulmonary embolism (38%) (Option B) Cardiac failure (18%) (Option A) Anastomotic leak (18%) (Option C) Respiratory failure (12%) (Option D) Most dreaded complication Anastomotic leak with overall morbidity of 61% and mortality of 15%. Maximum risk of anastomotic leak Gastrojejunal anastomosis (60-80%) Comparison across procedures Mortality rates for laparoscopic procedures were reported as: Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding: 0.06%, Vertical band gastroplasty: 0.21%, Roux-en-Y gastric bypass: 0.16%, Biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch: 1.11%. Higher mortality rates were found for open procedures compared to laparoscopic ones. Reference: Schwartz Principles of Surgery, 11th edition, Pages 1203,1204 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3249614/ https://tsaco.bmj.com/content/3/1/e000219

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient with a BMI of 38 kg/m² is considering weight loss surgery. The surgeon suggests a procedure that involves placing a band around the stomach just below the cardia to create a small gastric pouch. Which procedure is being recommended?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding Explanation: Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding: (Option D) Popularity decline Due to long-term results and alternatives. Procedure Uses the pars flaccida technique through the window of the lesser omentum. Band Placement: Positioned just below the esophagogastric junction to create a small virtual gastric pouch. Band Fixation: Sutured anteriorly with gastrogastric tunneling sutures to prevent slippage. Access Port: Sutured to the rectus sheath in the upper abdomen for easy access by a non-coring, Huber needle for adjustments. Types of adjustable bands Lapband (silicon) SAGB Image Mechanism of action Purely restrictive bariatric procedure. Reduces hunger, likely through vagal mediation. Treatment approach Initial Placement: Marks the start of treatment, requiring ongoing management. Band Adjustments: Involves specialist consultations to assess eating habits and then perform adjustments with injection or aspiration of saline to achieve optimal appetite control. Challenges Requires frequent adjustments, associated with patient frustration and lower compliance, impacting long-term weight loss. Follow up Monthly visits are recommended for the first year, with full multidisciplinary team (MDT) support. Complications Early: Access port infection (1%) Deep vein thrombosis(DVT)/ Pulmonary embolism (PE)(<0.1%) Late: Band infection Tubing leak Slippage Erosion into stomach Band intolerance Failure to lose weight/weight regain Intragastric Balloon Placement: (Option C) Method Minimally invasive, temporary procedure with an endoscopically placed balloon filled with saline or air into the stomach. Mechanism Balloon serves as a restrictive mechanism and promotes the feeling of satiation as it is a space-occupying device. Volume of balloon needed A 400 mL balloon or larger can effectively induce satiation. Effectiveness Can achieve 6-15% total body weight loss compared to lifestyle modification alone. FDA-Approved Balloons Obalon, Orbera, ReShape. Adverse Effects Common adverse effects: Pain, nausea, GERD, gastric ulcers, balloon migration Serious adverse effects: Small bowel obstruction, perforation, death. Patient Compliance Essential for success; Requires adherence to lifestyle modifications. Sleeve gastrectomy (Option A) involves resection of a large part of the stomach which regulates appetite, creating a tube-like structure. It is not a banding procedure. Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (Option B) involves the creation of a small gastric pouch from the proximal end of the stomach which is then connected with the distal jejunum, not a banding procedure.

questions.question: A 38-year-old woman with a BMI of 40 kg/m² undergoes sleeve gastrectomy. Post-surgery, she asks how the procedure helps her lose weight. What is the primary mechanism by which sleeve gastrectomy leads to weight loss?

options.A: Reduced stomach size and hormonal changes.
options.C: Reduced appetite with no hormonal impact.
options.D: Nutrient malabsorption due to intestinal bypass.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Reduced stomach size and hormonal changes. Explanation: Sleeve gastrectomy A recent, safe and effective surgical technique and a leading method in metabolic surgery for treating obesity with higher survival rates. Procedure Involves resection of a large part of the stomach, which regulates appetite. Does not require gastrointestinal anastomosis or intestinal bypass. Minimally invasive and less technically challenging. Image Mechanism of weight loss (Option A) Weight loss is achieved through both mechanical restriction (reduction of stomach size) and hormonal modulation (affecting hunger hormones such as ghrelin). Uses Weight Loss Reduce mental health problems Clinical Markers: Improve serum lipid profile, biochemical, histological, hematological and inflammatory markers. Obesity-related disease resolution: Better control of Type 2 diabetes, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, cardiovascular risk, obstructive sleep apnea and stroke risk. Non-obesity related disease remission: Reduced gout attacks, musculoskeletal pain, improved fertility and reduced pregnancy complications and lower cancer incidence. Complications Early Leak at angle of His (1-2%) Intra-abdominal bleed (2-3%) Deep vein thrombosis(DVT)/ Pulmonary embolism (PE)(<1%) Late Nutritional: Iron, vitamin B12, calcium,vitamin D deficiency Gastro-oesophageal reflux Barrett's esophagus Weight regain Complete removal of the stomach (Option B): Sleeve gastrectomy only involves removing a portion of the stomach, not the entire stomach. This procedure leaves behind a tubular sleeve of the stomach with reduced size but preserves its essential functions. Reduced appetite with no hormonal impact (Option C): Sleeve gastrectomy not only restricts calorie intake but also leads to significant hormonal changes, such as reduced ghrelin production (a hormone that stimulates appetite), which plays a crucial role in promoting satiety and weight loss. Nutrient malabsorption due to intestinal bypass (Option D): Sleeve gastrectomy does not involve bypassing any part of the intestine, rather it focuses on reducing the size of the stomach without altering the intestinal tract, so malabsorption is not a primary mechanism.

questions.question: A 52-year-old woman is recovering from a recent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery. She has been informed about the possible complications that can arise post-surgery. Which of the following is least likely to be a complication of her bypass surgery?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Pancreatitis Explanation: Pancreatitis directly following bariatric surgery is uncommon but can be fatal. Feature Mini-Gastric Bypass Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass Procedure Involves a longer tubular gastric pouch and then the distal end of the pouch is connected to jejunum about 150-250 cm from the ligament of Treitz. Involves the creation of a small gastric pouch from the proximal end of the stomach, which is then connected with the distal jejunum. Roux limb is varied between 100-150 cm. Weight loss Weight loss is by both restrictive and malabsorptive. Image No. of Anastomosis One: Gastro-jejunal anastomosis Two: Gastro-jejunal anastomosis Jejunal-jejunal anastomosis Complications Early: Anastomotic leak (<1 %) (Option A) Intra-abdominal bleed (2-3%) Unspecified obstruction (1-2%) Deep vein thrombosis(DVT)/ Pulmonary embolism (PE) (<1%) (Option D) Late: Internal hernia (Option B) Chronic abdominal pain Malnutrition if long limb bypass; Iron deficiency anemia; Vitamin B12 deficiency; Calcium deficiency Anastomotic ulcer/ stricture

questions.question: A 40-year-old obese male visits the surgical OPD. He is advised to undergo a biliopancreatic diversion and duodenal switch (BPD-DS) surgery. What would not be a possible indication for BPD-DS?

options.B: Failed another operation for weight loss

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Preexisting iron deficiency anemia Explanation: A preexisting anemia is a contraindication for BPD-DS. Biliopancreatic diversion: It begins with a distal subtotal gastrectomy with a residual 200mL gastric pouch. The terminal ileum is divided 250 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve. The distal end is then divided and anastomosed to the stomach. A 2 to 3-cm stoma is created. Proximal end of the ileum is anastomosed side-to-side to the terminal ileum. Cholecystectomy is done prophylactically due to the high incidence of gallstone formation with malabsorption of bile salts. Duodenal switch: The only difference is that instead of a distal gastrectomy, resection of all the stomach except for a narrow lesser curvature of the stomach is performed. The duodenum is then divided in its first portion. The end of the duodenum is anastomosed to the distal 250 cm of ileum. Distal bowel configuration and cholecystectomy are similar to BPD. Indications: Higher BMIs (Option A) Failed another operation for weight loss or metabolic control (Option B&C). Contraindications: Geographic distance from the surgeon Lack of financial means to afford supplements Preexisting calcium, iron or other nutrient deficiencies (Option D). Complications: Bleeding Leakage GI obstruction Wound infections Marginal ulcers after BPD that lead to the adoption of DS. Nutritional complications: Most common Protein malnutrition Iron deficiency anemia Bone demineralization Alopecia (protein deficiency) Night blindness (vitamin A deficiency) Gallstones if gall bladder not removed Protein-calorie malnutrition: most severe & life-threatening.

questions.question: In the preoperative assessment for obesity surgery, which of the following factors does NOT contribute to the obesity surgery mortality risk score?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Female gender Explanation: The obesity surgery mortality risk score includes factors such as BMI greater than 50 kg/m², male gender (not female), age greater than 45 years, hypertension, and risk factors for pulmonary thromboembolism. Obesity Surgery Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS): It is used to estimate the likelihood of mortality following bariatric surgery Risk factor Points BMI >50 kg/m 2 1 Male gender 1 Age >45 years 1 Hypertension 1 Risk factors for pulmonary thromboembolism 1 Risk group Score Postoperative mortality Low risk 0-1 0.3 Moderate risk 2-3 1.7 High risk 4-5 3.2 Risk factors for pulmonary thromboembolism: Prior venous thromboembolism, vena cava filter, hypoventilation, pulmonary hypertension. Reference: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/361425833_Preoperative_preparation_and_premedication_of _bariatric_surgical_patient

questions.question: A patient is evaluated for obesity in the hospital for bariatric surgery. Which of the following would not be an indication for the surgery? ≥ 40kg/m2 with no comorbidities ≥ 35kg/m2 with no comorbidities ≥ 37.5kg/m2 in Asian population with/without comorbidities
questions.explanation: ≥ 35kg/m2 with no comorbidities Correct Answer: B) BMI ≥ 35kg/m2 with no comorbidities Explanation: BMI ≥ 35kg/m2 with comorbidities is an indication of surgery and not without comorbidities. Indications for bariatric surgery: International Population Asian Population (metabolic surgery) BMI ≥ 40kg/m2 with/without comorbidities (Option A) BMI ≥ 35kg/m2 with comorbidities (Option B) BMI ≥ 37.5kg/m2 with/without comorbidities (Option D) BMI ≥ 32.5kg/m2 with comorbidities Failure of previous nonsurgical attempts at weight loss (Option C). A patient who is committed to postoperative care, follow-ups, medical management, and instructions for any tests and procedures. Reference: Schwartz Principles of Surgery, 11th edition, Pages 1173,1175.

questions.question: In which of the following situations is robotic surgery not suitable?

options.B: Surgeon suffers from tremors in hands

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Low-budget surgical setup Explanation: Robotic surgery is very expensive, so it is not suitable in a low-budget setup. It operates on a "master-slave" principle, with the surgeon (master) controlling the robot (slave) through hand movements. The robot’s wristed instruments replicate these movements precisely, avoiding the fulcrum issue of laparoscopic tools. This precision allows for fine motor skills in confined spaces. (Option A ruled out) Additionally, the robotic system includes filters to counteract tremors and can translate large movements into smaller, precise ones. (Option B ruled out) Remote operation is possible, making telesurgery feasible for hostile environments such as military, space missions, deep-sea exploration, and polar expeditions. Applied in: Prostatic surgery Gynecological surgeries (Option C ruled out) Some cardiac surgeries Urologic surgeries Endocrine surgery The disadvantages of robotic surgery: High cost Bulky and high setup time Significant resource requirements Trained personnel are still needed for patient preparation, port insertion, robot docking, instrument changes, and handling complications or unexpected issues. Reference: Sabiston’s Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Pages 353, 354. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1356187/

questions.question: Which of the following statements about per-oral endoscopic myotomy is false?

options.A: It is a modification of NOTES surgery
options.B: A flexible endoscope is used to create a submucosal tunnel
options.C: It is a good surgical technique for achalasia cardia
options.D: The procedure involves the division of longitudinal muscles

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) The procedure involves the division of longitudinal muscles. Explanation: Per-oral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) involves the division of the circular muscles of the esophagus. It is a modification of the NOTES procedure (Option A) . This is a natural orifice procedure. It is used for achalasia cardia (Option C) and is being tried for gastric outlet obstruction. Procedure: A flexible endoscope (Option B) is inserted into the esophagus and a long esophageal myotomy is created. Fluid is injected, and a submucosal tunnel is created. Then, the circular muscle fibres (Option D) are divided Once the procedure is completed, hemostatic clips are applied at the incision site. Reference: Sabiston’s Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page 352.

questions.question: A 20-year-old female comes to the OPD for an elective abdominal surgery. She is worried about developing a scar and enquires about a scarless procedure. Which among the following surgical procedures gives a scarless result?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery Explanation: The Natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery (NOTES) surgery is scarless as it is done via the natural body orifices (rectum, mouth, vagina). This technique can be applied to the pelvis , abdomen, and thorax . Closure of the visceral puncture site is a major issue that has prevented the uptake of this method. Transgastric, trans colonic closure of peritoneal entry sites in a safe way remains a problem. Significant cost and training implications have also limited more widespread adoption. Appendectomy and cholecystectomy are done with this method. Staging of intra-abdominal malignancy, segmental colectomy, and gastro-jejunostomy are also performed this way. Advantages : Complications like hernias and wound infections are also eliminated. Usage of a flexible endoscope used in NOTES allows access to remote areas of the peritoneal cavity more easily and quickly. Laparoscopic abdominal surgery (Option A), even though it leaves a very minimal scar, is not a scarless procedure. Laparotomy (Option B) has a midline incision along the linea alba that leaves a long scar. Hand-assisted laparoscopic surgery (Option D) involves the intra-abdominal placement of a hand or forearm through a mini-laparotomy incision while the pneumoperitoneum is maintained.

questions.question: A 25-year-old female who underwent a simple mastectomy was admitted in the hospital and discharged on the same day after the procedure. What type of surgery is this?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Day surgery Explanation: Day surgery (Option A) or daycare surgery is the admission of selected patients to a hospital for a planned surgical procedure, returning home on the same day. “True day surgery” patients are those who need full operating theatre facilities and/or a general anesthetic, and any day cases are not included as outpatients or undergoing endoscopy. Fast-track surgery (Option B) is a multimodal approach. It uses a combination of several evidence-based peri-operative interventions to improve recovery after surgery. It includes preoperative interventions like Evaluating and optimizing existing organ function Nutritional status Patient education about the entire process Minimal starvation (2h- liquids, 6h- solids) Oral carbohydrate drink No mechanical bowel preparation Operative interventions: Preoperative antibiotics, acid suppression, and pro-kinetic premedications Thoracic epidural analgesia Nasogastric decompression, urinary catheterization, and abdominal drainage Goal-directed fluid administration Maintain normothermia Minimal tissue handling Minimize operative time Minimal access surgery Post-operative measures: Multimodal, pre-emptive, and adequate analgesia Postop nausea and vomiting prophylaxis and/or treatment Early removal of all drains and tubes if inserted Early enteral nutrition Early enforced ambulation Ensure follow-up after discharge If a surgery requires a 23-hour stay with an overnight stay it is not day surgery. It is an overnight stay surgery (Option C) and the patient is discharged early morning. In short-stay surgeries (Option D) , the patient is admitted for 72 hours. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4173620/

questions.question: A laparoscopic surgery was done on a patient for cholecystitis, and he later complained of shoulder pain. What would be the most possible cause for this?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Splenic trauma Explanation: Splenic trauma leads to bleeding, and this causes a collection of blood under the diaphragm ( Kehr’s sign ). This leads to the irritation of the diaphragm and referred pain via the phrenic nerve , hence the shoulder pain . This can also be due to CO2 used for insufflation that irritates the diaphragm. An intraabdominal abscess (Option A) is the most common complication that is seen in laparoscopic appendectomy. Mesenteric bleeding (Option B) , enterotomy, and ureteric injury are intraoperative complications seen in laparoscopic colectomy. Perforation of the esophagus (Option C) or stomach, splenectomy, and pneumothorax is the most commonly reported intraoperative complications of laparoscopic antireflux surgery. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK6923/

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient is about to undergo a cholecystectomy. He has no other comorbidities and wants a minimally invasive surgery; hence, the surgeon suggests a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Which of the following gases is most widely used for creating a pneumoperitoneum?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Carbon dioxide Explanation: Carbon dioxide is the most frequently used gas for pneumoperitoneum, considering its inert quality and non-inflammable characteristics. CO2 insufflation is started slowly until an abdominal pressure of 12-15mmHg is reached. Although carbon dioxide meets most of the requirements for pneumoperitoneum, the absorption of CO2 may be associated with adverse events like cardiopulmonary complications and adverse events in people with high anesthetic risk which is avoided by hyperventilation. Other gases used for creating a pneumoperitoneum: Room air (Option A) has no cardiopulmonary complications or serious adverse effects and could be cheaper. It also showed less pain on the first post op day. However, the evidence was of low quality and hence not widely used. Oxygen (Option B) is a gas that aids combustion. The usage of oxygen with electrocautery in surgeries would lead to dangerous outcomes. Helium (Option D) was also studied to create a pneumoperitoneum. Not enough evidence was obtained about the cardiopulmonary effects of using helium. Serious adverse effects like subcutaneous emphysema were also noted. Nitrous oxide is also used for creating a pneumoperitoneum. No adverse effects were found, and has a lower pain score. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6481852/

questions.question: A diabetic patient with severe sepsis develops a persistent urinary tract infection (UTI) despite antibiotic treatment. The infection control team suspects a multidrug-resistant pathogen. Which of the following is true about nosocomial infections? devices.

options.A: Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of hospital-acquired respiratory infections.
options.B: Klebsiella is a frequent cause of drug-resistant hospital-acquired UTIs.
options.C: Nosocomial infections are not typically transmitted between patients.
options.D: Patients with artificial prostheses are less prone to nosocomial infections than those with indwelling

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Klebsiella is a frequent cause of drug-resistant hospital-acquired UTIs respiratory infections . (Option A) For respiratory tract infections, pathogens such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus, and Pneumocystis carinii are more common. Hospital Acquired Infections: Acquired infections after 48 hours of hospital admission that were neither present nor incubating at the time of admission. Spread by healthcare workers or between patients if aseptic measures are not followed. High-Risk Patients Diabetics Immunosuppressed individuals Patients on steroids, life-supporting machines. Instrumentation (indwelling catheter, IV cannula, tracheostomy tube) Patients with artificial prostheses Common Pathogens Wound infection: Staphylococcus aureus (most common), Pseudomonas, Klebsiella, E.coli, Proteus. Respiratory tract infections: Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus, Herpes, Varicella, Aspergillus, Pneumocystis carinii. UTIs: Klebsiella (most common). Antibiotic-associated diarrhea: Clostridium difficile. Management Most organisms invading are multidrug-resistant and virulent and hence cause severe sepsis. Antibiotics based on culture results. Blood, urine, pus for culture and sensitivity to isolate the organisms. Supportive care (e.g., ventilator, nutrition, maintaining optimum urine output). Prevention Isolate infected patients. Follow strict aseptic practices. Disinfect facilities, treat underlying conditions and proper nutrition. Klebsiella is indeed a frequent pathogen responsible for hospital-acquired urinary tract infections and is notably resistant to multiple drugs, making it a major concern in nosocomial infections. (Option B) Nosocomial infections can and do spread between patients. Transmission can occur through direct patient contact or contaminated equipment. (Option C) Patients with artificial prostheses are actually at increased risk for nosocomial infections compared to those with indwelling devices, due to the potential for infection at the site of the prosthesis and the complexity of managing such infections. (Option D) Reference: SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 59, 60

questions.question: A 55-year-old woman, 4 days post-abdominal surgery, reports a sudden feeling of popping at her surgical site followed by the drainage of pinkish fluid. On examination, there is partial wound dehiscence with no visible bowel protrusion. What is the next best step in management?

options.B: Apply a wound vacuum system and monitor
options.D: Place an abdominal binder and observe

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Prompt reclosure of the fascia Explanation: Wound Dehiscence Disruption of any or all of the layers in a wound. Occurrence Up to 3% of abdominal wounds; most commonly occurs between the 5th and 8th postoperative days. Types Partial dehiscence: Involves only the skin and subcutaneous fat. Complete dehiscence: Involves the fascial layer and may include evisceration (extrusion of abdominal viscera). Risk Factors General: Malnourishment Diabetes Obesity Renal failure Jaundice Sepsis Cancer Treatment with steroids Emergency surgery Local: Inadequate or poor closure of wound or closure of a wound under tension Poor local wound healing Increased intra-abdominal pressure Clinical Presentation Pinkish serosanguinous discharge (salmon-coloured fluid), Possible evisceration, Popping sensation during straining or coughing. Treatment Partial dehiscence (without evisceration): Prompt reclosure of the fascia is generally advised. (Option A) Complete dehiscence with evisceration: Requires urgent reoperation. Tension suturing is done. Protect eviscerated bowel with moist towels; handle carefully to prevent injury. Antibiotic therapy; fluid management. Wound vacuums aid healing by reducing fluid and improving blood flow, but they are better for chronic wounds. (Option B) For partial dehiscence with intact fascia, prompt reclosure is needed, making this option less suitable. Antibiotics may be necessary if the infection is present, but discharging without addressing the dehiscence risks worsening into complete dehiscence and evisceration. (Option C) An abdominal binder supports intra-abdominal pressure but does not resolve the dehiscence. (Option D) Surgical reclosure of the fascia is required to prevent further complications.

questions.question: A 68-year-old man develops a fever of 101.5°F on postoperative day 5 after total hip replacement. He also has localized pain and swelling in his left calf. The chest X-ray is normal, and there are no respiratory symptoms. What is the most likely cause of his fever?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Thrombophlebitis Explanation: Causes of Postoperative Fever Immediate Fever: Fever occurs immediately after surgery or within hours on postoperative days (POD) 0 or 1. Malignant Hyperthermia Bacteremia Gas gangrene of the wound (Option D) Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction Acute Fever: Fever occurs in the first week (POD 1 to 7). POD 1: Pyretic response to surgery POD 3: Unresolved atelectasis resulting in pneumonia; development of urinary tract infection (UTI) POD 5: Thrombophlebitis (Option B) POD 7: Pulmonary embolism (Option A) POD 7 (5 to 10): Wound infection Subacute Fever: Fever occurs between postoperative weeks 1 and 4. POD 10: Deep infections (Option C) Drugs reactions Delayed Fever: Fever after >4 weeks. Skin and soft tissue infection (SSTI) Viral infections Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482299/

questions.question: In the operating room, the surgical team is completing the WHO Surgical Safety Checklist. They are focused on final checks before closing the incision. Which of the following is not a standard checklist item at this stage?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Checking the patient’s COVID-19 status. Explanation: The WHO Surgical Safety Checklist focuses on critical safety measures directly related to the surgical procedure, and checking the patient's COVID-19 status is not part of the standard checklist items during final checks before closing the incision. WHO Surgical Safety Checklist: Intended to give surgical teams a simple and efficient set of priority checks to ensure patient safety, effective teamwork, and communication in every operation performed. Identifies specific checks to be carried out at three obligatory time points. The initial results of the implementation of the WHO checklist showed a decrease in surgical site infections from 6.2% to 3.4% and a decrease in the death rate from 1.5% to 0.8%. Checklists are effective with: Early engagement of staff; Active leadership and identification of local champions; Extensive discussion, education, and training; Multidisciplinary involvement; Coaching; Ongoing feedback; Local adaptation. Checklists alone are not a complete solution; they need to be part of a broader safety strategy.

questions.question: A 50-year-old man develops sudden respiratory distress, altered consciousness and hypotension during a craniotomy surgery. The anesthesiologist hears a mill-wheel murmur and suspects an air embolism. What is the most appropriate immediate action?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Place in Trendelenburg position. Explanation: Air Embolism Occurs when air enters accidentally into the vascular system.Commonly iatrogenic via interventional procedures, but also from trauma, diving, childbirth, and other circumstances. Causes Through venous access like IV cannula. Artificial Pneumothorax. Surgeries of neck and axilla. Traumatic opening of major veins sucking air inside. Fallopian tube insufflation. Laparoscopic surgeries. Illegal abortions. Symptoms Respiratory Distress, Hemoptysis, Convulsions, Unconsciousness, Visual and hearing disturbances, Fatigue and numbness, Paralysis, Hemodynamic instability, Coma. Diagnosis Patient history especially relation to recent procedures. Auscultation: Millwheel murmur heard over the precordium is diagnostic. ECG: ST depression and right heart strain due to pulmonary artery obstruction. Capnometry: Decreased end-tidal CO2 levels in intubated patients. Imaging: Chest X-ray, Doppler ultrasonography, transesophageal echocardiography (TEE). Treatment Positioning: Trendelenburg position: Keeps air bubbles away from coronary arteries. (Option C) Left lateral decubitus position: Helps trap air in the non-dependent segment of the right ventricle, preventing it from entering the pulmonary artery. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy: Useful in both venous and arterial air embolism as it reduces ischemia, bubble size; in arterial embolism it removes nitrogen from bubbles to improve perfusion and oxygenation. Aspiration: Air should be aspirated from the right ventricle with a needle. Open Thoracotomy: Life-saving procedure required to aspirate excess air causing the block. Administer a diuretic (Option A): Diuretics are used to manage fluid overload and do not address the issue of air in the circulation. They do not prevent or mitigate the effects of an air embolism. Perform CPR (Option B): CPR is necessary only if the patient is in cardiac arrest. In this case, the priority is to address the air embolism, not perform CPR. Epinephrine (Option C): Is used for cardiac arrest or severe allergic reactions, not specifically for managing air embolism. The immediate focus should be on positioning to prevent further complications. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1014 SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 188, 189 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3665124/

questions.question: A 55-year-old female patient is scheduled for lateral thoracotomy. The surgical team prepares to position her on the operating table. Which position should the patient be placed in for optimal access to the thorax?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Lateral Decubitus Position Explanation: Positioning on Operating Table: Position Description Uses and Complications Supine Position Most common position for general surgical procedures. Modifications of Supine position: Rose’s position Shoulder and Arm Extended Trendelenburg Position Reverse Trendelenburg Position Fowler's Position General surgeries. Rose's Position Supine with slight neck extension. Head and neck surgery. Shoulder and Arm Extended Supine with shoulder and arm extended. Axillary and breast surgery. Trendelenburg Position (Option D) Head end tilted down, knees slightly flexed. Pelvic procedures, resuscitating patients in shock. Reverse Trendelenburg Position Head end tilted upward, placing the head higher than the feet. Upper abdominal surgeries. Complication: Right shoulder pain due to CO2 collected under the right dome of diaphragm during laparoscopic cholecystectomy Fowler's Position Semi-sitting with trunk raised at 40° and knees bent. Neurosurgery, shoulder surgeries, patients with heart or respiratory failure. Complication: Increased risk of air embolism. Prone Position Patient is intubated and log-rolled onto the operating bed with help. Spinal surgery, extra levator abdominoperineal excision for rectal cancer. Jackknife Position (Option A) (Prone Position Modification) Chest supported, abdomen relaxed by flexing at the hips. Provides excellent access to the perineum. Complication: Positional asphyxia Lateral Decubitus or Kidney Position (Option B) Lower leg flexed, pillow between legs, upper leg flexed in an exaggerated position. Draining abscesses, lateral thoracotomy, urological and retroperitoneal procedures. Complication: Increased risk of brachial plexus injury due to hyperextension Lithotomy Position (Option C) Supine with hips and knees flexed, legs in stirrups, hips flexed to 90°. Gynecological, perineal, and urological procedures. Complication: Common peroneal nerve injury if legs are not supported properly Lloyd-Davies Position (Lithotomy Modification) Supine with hips minimally flexed (~15°) and a 30° head-down tilt. Gynecological, perineal, and urological procedures. questions.question: A patient’s wound, evaluated on postoperative day 7, shows signs of erythema, pain and swelling with no discharge and deep tissue involvement. What is the likely Southampton wound grading?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Grade II Explanation: The patient shows erythema and signs of inflammation with no discharge, so according to Southampton wound grading, it is classified as Grade II. Surgical Site Infection is defined as Wound infection which occurs within 30 days of surgery or if an implant is placed within 1 year of surgery. It is the second most common complication following surgical procedures due to virulent bacterial entry, altered wound microenvironment, and changed host defense. Scoring systems for severity of wound infection: Southampton wound grading system Grade Appearance Subtypes 0 Normal healing I (Option A) Normal healing with mild bruising or erythema A: Some bruising B: Considerable bruising C: Mild erythema II (Option B) Erythema plus other signs of inflammation A: At 1 point B: Around sutures C: Along wound D: Around wound III (Option C) Clear or haemoserous discharge A: At 1 point only (<2 cm) B: Along wound (>2 cm) C: Large volume D: Prolonged (>3 days) IV (Option D) Pus A: At 1 point only (<2 cm) B: Along wound (>2 cm) V Deep or severe infection with or without tissue breakdown; haematoma requiring aspiration Asepsis wound score Parameters Score A dditional treatment: Antibiotics Pus drainage Wound debridement 10 5 10 S erous discharge - For 5 days of first 7 days of wound infection 0-5 Daily E rythema - For 5 days of first 7 days of wound infection 0-5 Daily P urulent fluid - For 5 days of first 7 days of wound infection 0-10 Daily S eparation of deep tissues - For 5 days of first 7 days of wound infection 0-10 Daily I solation of bacteria 10 S tay in the hospital (in-patient) >14 days due to infection 5 Asepsis scores are grouped into the following categories: Satisfactory healing: 0-10, Disturbance of healing:11-20, Minor SSI: 21-30, Moderate SSI: 31-40, Severe SSI: >40. Reference: SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 34,62 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6505358/

questions.question: Which of the following correctly matches the zone in an OT (Operating Theatre) complex with its primary function?

options.A: Protective zone: Includes the sterile operation rooms.
options.B: Clean zone: Primarily contains the change rooms for medical and paramedical staff.
options.C: Aseptic zone: Contains the sterile operating rooms.
options.D: Disposal zone: Connected directly to the aseptic zone and contains the patient transfer bay.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Aseptic zone: Contains the sterile operating rooms. Explanation: The protective zone includes areas such as change rooms, transfer bays, and pre/post-operative rooms, but it does not contain the sterile operating rooms. The Clean zone (Option A) connects the protective zone to the aseptic zone. It is designed to further reduce contamination. It typically contains: Clean rooms for preparation Storage for surgical instruments Areas for surveillance and maintenance Emergency exit routes The Aseptic zone (Option B) includes the sterile operating rooms where surgeries are performed, and maintaining a high degree of cleanliness is critical. The Disposal zone (Option D) is where waste from the operating rooms is collected and managed, but it is not directly connected to the patient transfer bay, which is part of the protective zone. Reference: https://journals.lww.com/ijaweb/fulltext/2007/51030/designing_an_ideal_operating_room_complex.5.aspx

questions.question: Which of the following strategies is most effective in preventing surgical site infections (SSIs) during an operation? the operating room (OR). OR.

options.A: Administering prophylactic antibiotics before the first incision and maintaining positive pressure in
options.B: Using concentric circles for antisepsis application and maintaining the OR temperature at 18 ± 3°C.
options.C: Administering antibiotics after the operation and maintaining a negative pressure differential in the
options.D: Avoiding alcohol-based antiseptic solutions and using antibiotics with a short tissue half-life.

questions.explanation: positive pressure in the operating room (OR). Correct Answer: A) Administering prophylactic antibiotics before the first incision and maintaining positive pressure in the operating room. Explanation: Administering prophylactic antibiotics before the first incision ensures that maximal antibiotic levels are present in the tissues when the incision is made, reducing the risk of bacterial contamination during surgery. Maintaining a positive pressure differential in the OR helps keep outside air from entering the sterile environment, which is crucial for preventing airborne contamination and thus reducing SSIs. (Option A) Prophylactic Considerations Details Prophylactic Antibiotics Administered before the first incision to ensure maximal antibiotic levels are present in tissues at the time of incision, reducing the risk of bacterial contamination. (Option C) Operating Room (OR) Air Pressure Positive pressure differential in the OR is essential to keep outside air from entering, preventing airborne contamination and reducing the risk of Surgical Site Infections (SSIs). (Option C) Antisepsis Application Technique Concentric circles are often used, but WHO guidelines state that the specific pattern (concentric circles, horizontal or vertical) does not significantly impact SSI prevention. (Option B) Operating Room Temperature Recommended OR temperature is 21 ± 3°C. A temperature of 18°C is too low, potentially causing hypothermia in patients, negatively affecting wound healing and outcomes. (Option B) Skin Antisepsis Solution Alcohol-based solutions like chlorhexidine alcohol are recommended for skin antisepsis because of their effectiveness in reducing transient organisms and preventing SSIs. (Option D) Antibiotic Selection Antibiotics with a short half-life might not maintain adequate tissue levels throughout surgery. Long-acting antibiotics or those that can be re-dosed during long surgeries are preferred. (Option D) Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 61. https://www.nabh.co/Images/PDF/Operation-Theatre-Guidelines.pdf

questions.question: A 62-year-old man with hypovolemic shock requires rapid fluid resuscitation. Which of the following IV catheters would be most appropriate for this situation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 14G orange catheter Explanation: The 14G orange catheter is the most appropriate for rapid fluid resuscitation in hypovolemic shock. Larger gauge (smaller number) catheters allow for higher flow rates, which is crucial in emergencies requiring rapid volume replacement. IV Catheter Gauge, Color, and Flow Rates Gauge Color Flow Rate (mL/min) Typical Use 14 Orange 270 Rapid transfusion, trauma, Large volume replacement 16 Gray 236 Large volume infusion, blood transfusions 18 Green 103 Blood products, contrast study, surgery 20 Pink 67 General IV access 22 Blue 42 Small, fragile veins 24 Yellow 20 Pediatric use Reference: Equipment in Anaesthesia and Critical Care, 1st Edition, Page 264.

questions.question: A 28-year-old man from a resource-poor area presents with a 3-week history of fever, abdominal pain, and altered bowel habits. Abdominal examination reveals a doughy feel and a mass in the right iliac fossa. Which finding would most likely distinguish intestinal tuberculosis from typhoid fever in this patient?

options.B: Positive blood culture for Salmonella Typhi
options.C: Multiple longitudinal ulcers in the terminal ileum

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Caseating granulomas on intestinal biopsy Explanation: Caseating granulomas on intestinal biopsy are characteristic of intestinal tuberculosis and would distinguish it from typhoid fever. In tuberculosis, Histology shows caseating granuloma with giant cells. This finding is not seen in typhoid fever and is highly suggestive of tuberculosis. Evening rise in temperature (Option A) is seen in both conditions. Hence, this feature is not specific and cannot be used to distinguish intestinal tuberculosis from typhoid fever. Positive blood culture for Salmonella Typhi (Option B) would confirm typhoid fever, not distinguish it from tuberculosis. Multiple longitudinal ulcers in the terminal ileum (Option C) can be seen in Typhoid. Transverse ulcers with typically undermined edges are seen in tuberculosis. Features of Intestinal TB vs Typhoid: Feature Intestinal Tuberculosis Typhoid (Enteric Fever) Causative Organism Mycobacterium tuberculosis Salmonella typhi Mode of Transmission Ingestion of food contaminated with tubercle bacilli Fecal-oral route Gross Appearance (Ulcer Description) Ulcers are transverse, often circumferential, forming a "girdle" shape. Typically multiple ulcers. Located mostly in the Ileocaecal region. Ulcers are longitudinal, multiple and arranged in a parallel and antimesenteric pattern. Often occur in the terminal ileum and Peyer's patches. Ulcers can perforate, leading to peritonitis. Microscopic Features Presence of granulomas with caseating necrosis. Epithelioid cells and Langhans giant cells are common. Lymphoid hypertrophy is noted. Neutropenia and splenomegaly may also be observed. Clinical Presentation Dull, colicky abdominal pain, often in the right iliac fossa. Weight loss, fever, and anemia are common. Mass may be felt in the right iliac fossa (indicating ileocaecal involvement). Presents initially with fever, chills, and abdominal pain. Severe diarrhea, relative bradycardia, and abdominal tenderness are common. Complications Intestinal obstruction due to stricture formation. Risk of bowel perforation and fistula formation. Intestinal hemorrhage. Perforation leading to faecal peritonitis. Paralytic ileus is a common complication. Diagnostic Features Histology: Granulomas, Langhans giant cells and caseating necrosis are diagnostic. IFN- γ release assays Widal test, blood cultures positive for S. typhi. PCR assay for typhoid is also useful. X-ray may show gas under the diaphragm if perforation is present. Treatment Anti-tubercular therapy Antibiotics (e.g., cephalosporins)

questions.question: A 48-year-old male immigrant presents with a painless, fluctuating mass in the neck that has been gradually enlarging over 2 months, along with an evening rise in temperature and weight loss. On examination, there is a 3 cm soft, non-tender swelling in the left posterior triangle of the neck without signs of inflammation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Excisional biopsy Explanation: The patient’s clinical features—a 3 cm soft, non-tender swelling in the left posterior triangle of the neck without signs of inflammation, an evening rise in temperature, and weight loss —are consistent with Tuberculous Lymphadenitis. It is the commonest form of extrapulmonary tuberculosis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Excisional biopsy is the most appropriate next step for definitive diagnosis and management . If the mass is still in the early stages of adenitis, an excision biopsy should be done. Incision and drainage (Option A) is incorrect because this is likely a cold abscess from tuberculous lymphadenitis. Incision and drainage can lead to chronic sinus formation and is not recommended. Fine needle aspiration cytology (Option B) is useful but not as superior as open node biopsy. False negative, false positive results and altering the node architecture, and so eventual need of open biopsy are the problems. Empiric antitubercular therapy (Option D) without a definitive diagnosis is inappropriate. Diagnosis should be confirmed before initiating treatment. Features of Tuberculous Lymphadenitis: Category Details Causative Organism Mycobacterium tuberculosis Common Sites Neck lymph nodes (80%), especially upper deep cervical (jugulodigastric - 54%) Posterior triangle lymph nodes (22%) Clinical Features Firm, matted lymph nodes Cold abscess formation Sinus formation with yellowish caseating discharge Gross Pathology Firm, matted lymph nodes with yellowish caseating material on cut section Microscopic Features Epithelioid cells with caseating material Langhans giant cells Stages 1. Lymphadenitis: Discrete, firm/hard, mobile, non-tender nodes 2. Matting: Nodes move together en masse due to periadenitis 3. Cold Abscess: Deep to deep fascia 4. Collar-stud Abscess: Rupture through the deep fascia, adherent to skin 5. Sinus Formation: Discharges yellowish caseating material Types Hyperplastic: 20% cases, discrete, firm, or hard nodes Caseating: 75-80% cases, matted nodes, often with cold abscess Atrophic: Rare, small atrophied nodes, caseating type Investigation FNAC: Useful for detecting epithelioid cells and Langhans giant cells Ultrasound neck: Node size, matting, cold abscess, and sinus tracking Chest X-ray: To detect associated pulmonary tuberculosis Mantoux test: May be useful but not very reliable CT neck and chest: For nodal status Treatment Antitubercular Drugs: Rifampicin, INH, Ethambutol, Pyrazinamide (for 6-9 months) Aspiration: Cold abscess is aspirated to prevent sinus formation Incision and Drainage: If abscess

questions.question: A 56-year-old diabetic male presents with severe leg pain, swelling, dusky discoloration, and bullae, 24 hours after a minor cut. The leg is edematous with crepitus, and the patient is febrile and tachycardic, showing signs of septic shock. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Immediate surgical debridement Explanation: The patient in the scenario presents with symptoms strongly indicative of necrotizing fasciitis , a rapidly progressing and life-threatening soft tissue infection. Therefore, the most appropriate management method is immediate surgical debridement. Necrotizing fasciitis It is a severe, rapidly spreading infection that produces necrosis of the subcutaneous tissues and overlying skin associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Cause Most common: Group A β -haemolytic Streptococci. Occasionally Staphylococcus aureus. Can be polymicrobial, involving Bacteroides, Clostridium, Proteus, Pseudomonas and Klebsiella. Forms Fournier's gangrene: Affects the perineal area. Meleney's gangrene: Involves the abdominal wall. Pathology Acute inflammatory infiltrate. Extensive necrosis, edema, and thrombosis of microvasculature. Dusky blue and black skin, bullae and progress to cutaneous gangrene. Rapid spread with possible skip lesions, later coalesce. Accompanied by fever, severe toxicity, and potential renal failure due to septic shock. Predisposing Conditions Diabetes mellitus, Smoking, Penetrating trauma, Pressure sores, Immunosuppression, Intravenous drug abuse, Perineal infections, Skin damage/infection. Signs and Symptoms Local: Unusual pain, Erythema, edema, warmth, Crepitus, Blisters, bullae, Grayish drainage (dishwasher pus), Fixed staining, Necrosis, gangrene. Systemic: Fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, Shock, Coagulopathy, Multiorgan failure. Diagnosis Based on clinical presentation. Elevated creatinine kinase levels. Biopsy of fascial layers confirms diagnosis. Radiographs may show air in tissues. Management Immediate ICU admission with monitoring of volume status and cardiac function. Administer oxygen; intubate if necessary. High-dose IV penicillin G and broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., third-generation cephalosporins, metronidazole). Immediate, aggressive surgical excision with daily dressing changes. Multiple debridements may be needed. Large wounds may require skin grafting or flap coverage. Vacuum-assisted dressings and early skin grafting aid healing and minimize fluid loss. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy can reduce mortality. Mortality Between 30% and 50%, even with prompt operative intervention. Image Monitor and observe (Option A) are inadequate for necrotising fasciitis due to its rapid progression and high mortality rate if not treated aggressively. IV fluids and pain management (Option B) are supportive measures, but they do not address the source of the infection. Immediate surgical debridement is essential to remove necrotic tissue and halt the infection. Intravenous antibiotics (Option C) are

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with severe muscle pain and swelling in his leg following a gunshot wound. The wound has a foul-smelling, brown discharge and shows signs of crepitus. X-rays reveal gas in the soft tissues. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Gas Gangrene Explanation: Gas Gangrene A rapidly progressive, potentially fatal condition characterized by widespread necrosis of muscles and soft-tissue destruction, often due to late-presenting missile wounds or crushing injuries. Cause Clostridium perfringens Incubation period <24 hours but ranges from 1 hour to 6 weeks Sources and predisposing factors Contaminated soil and feces. Wounds with necrotic or foreign material. Crush wounds, road traffic accidents, amputations. Anaerobic environments in the wound. Common sites of infection Adductor region of the lower limb and buttocks. Subscapular region in the upper limb. Clinical features Severe pain with limb swelling rapidly increases in severity. Serosanguineous discharge. Skin turns brown to blue-black with hemorrhagic bullae. Sweet, sticky odor & Soft-tissue crepitus. Complication Septicaemia, toxemia, renal failure, liver failure. Circulatory failure, DIC, secondary infections. Death occurs in critically ill patients. Investigation X-ray: Gas in soft tissues. Gram stain & blood culture: Large Gram-positive bacilli without neutrophils. Biochemical profile: Metabolic acidosis, renal failure. Peripheral blood smear: Haemolysis. CT scan for chest or abdominal wounds. Treatment High-dose intravenous penicillin and clindamycin, along with 3rd generation cephalosporins, are given intravenously. Polyvalent antiserums given intravenously. All dead tissues are excised, and debridement is performed until healthy tissue bleeds. Amputation done in severe cases Hyperbaric oxygen therapy. Prevention Proper debridement of devitalized crushed wounds. Devitalized wounds should not be sutured. Adequate cleaning of wounds with H I O I and normal saline. Penicillin - As a prophylactic antibiotic. Image Hidradenitis Suppurativa (Option A): Chronic inflammatory skin condition affecting apocrine sweat glands; lacks rapid progression, gas formation, or systemic signs. Fournier’s Gangrene (Option B): Severe, rapidly progressing infection of the scrotal skin and subcutaneous tissue, leading to gangrene, but localized to the perineum and genitals. Cellulitis (Option D): Deep skin infection affecting dermis and subcutaneous tissue, presenting with swelling, redness, and warmth but without gas formation or foul odour.

questions.question: A 55-year-old diabetic male presents with a 2-day history of increasing redness, warmth, and swelling in his left leg and also has fever and chills. The erythema is rapidly expanding, with no clear demarcation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Cellulitis Explanation: Feature Erysipelas (Option C) Cellulitis (Option B) Carbuncle (Option A) Definition Localized, sharply demarcated infection of upper dermis, often with broken skin. Generalized deeper infection affecting dermis and subcutaneous tissue. Infection of hair follicles extending into surrounding and subcutaneous tissue. Cause Beta-hemolytic Streptococcus pyogenes . Streptococcus pyogenes , Staphylococcus aureus . Staphylococcus aureus . Common Sites Lower limb, face, ear lobule, orbit. Lower limb, upper limb, face, scrotum. Nape of neck, back. Symptoms Erythematous, edematous rash; fever, leukocytosis, toxemia; raised rash with sharp margins; serous discharge; Milian's ear sign. Diffuse expanding erythema, painful, swelling; fever, malaise, toxicity; lymphangitis; no clear edge or limit to infection. Red, painful nodule; tender, fluctuant lesion; multiple draining sinuses; fever, lymphadenopathy. Complications Septicemia, localized gangrene, abscess, pneumonia, meningitis, lymphedema, recurrence (20%). Pyogenic abscess, bacteremia, septicemia, local gangrene, necrotizing fasciitis. Septicemia, abscess, necrosis, requiring possible excision or skin graft. Treatment Broad-spectrum antibiotics; penicillins, clindamycin; long-term penicillin for recurrence. Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics; elevation, glycerine-magnesium sulfate dressing. Control of diabetes; antibiotics; drainage, debridement, possible excision. Image Necrotizing fasciitis (Option D): Rapidly spreading inflammation of the skin, deep fascia and soft tissues with extensive destruction and more severe systemic symptoms, which is not consistent with the scenario.
